comments.commentBody:
Congressional Republicans have abandoned the legislative process because they only care about getting reelected. As reported by Bill Fram (AP), after they successfully blocked the bill to improve veteran's benefits, many assured the press they weren't worried about their votes affecting the mid-terms because the focus of the 2014 election would be on other things like Obamacare. How confident they are they can manipulate the press and the public.

Senator Richard Burr (R-NC), the top Republican on the Veterans' Affairs Committee, said after the vote, "We're sort of fooling ourselves to believe that this drives the election issue list." Clearly, our veterans did not make this "list."

Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama won the prize for rank hypocrisy when he stated, "We're going to do the right things for the veterans of America" and then voted to block the legislation.

For those who run for office to serve the common good, such behavior has to be hard to bear. There is a picture of Senator Bernie Sanders standing alone when the bill he worked so hard to pass was blocked. It says it all.*

*http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Latest-News-Wires/2014/0227/Republicans-blo...
Dear Bryan - perhaps Walter was just "ruffling the feathers of those who believe they are impervious to criticism"?

Six paragraphs in: "The Clintons don't get defeated. They get postponed." So did Reagan, by Strom Thurmond, (Against Nixon.) McCain. Romney. Especially Harold Stassen. The point?

Advocacy needs facts not postponed, obsessively.

Eight graphs in: "politically, we keep traveling to the past." A thesis! Supported by Lanny Davis and recycled resumes on runways!

Be real.

Arguments that appeal to authority are the exactly the opposite fallacy of those that indict the source ("a mere hiccup," the genetic fallacy and begging the question).

Monica? Stale stuff.

Snarky can be packaged in great craft. A thesis can be offered before the repeated "bunker mentality" buries it to end in a question asked, hinted at, but unanswered--by ignoring lots of real data from Senate votes and State, without Cruz's crutch of Dr. Seuss.

Who, by the way, had great craft.

@Bryan Barrett:  Samuel Johnson had it right when it cam to writing and criticism:  "He that writes may be considered as a kind of general challenger, whom every one has a right to attack; since he quits the common rank of life, steps forward beyond the lists, and offers his merit to the public judgement. To commence author is to claim praise, and no man can justly aspire to honour, but at the hazard of disgrace."  So you needn't be so outraged on Maureen Dowd's behalf.  I'm sure she understand that criticism goes with the territory of writing an opinion column.  She dishes out enough of it, after all
Pardon me while I belch. The diet of Dowd's blame and lies no longer agrees with me.

Thanks, Suzanne Mettler, for a great piece. I have long thought that being rich leads to college, much more than the other way around.

Serious research at the Santa Fe institute shows that your financial future depends on your family background, not on education (except for low income African Americans). This has serious implications for what the country should do.

Specifically, it means that more education is not likely to solve the employment problem. But improving everyone's family background might. That is the idea behind Welfare For All, a humorous name for an approach that has been tried successfully in Canada and on US Indian reservations.

To see more about this and other great ideas, go to YouTube and watch Comedy Party Platform (1 min 25 sec). And please vote for me -- I will support all the education people can absorb, plus a guaranteed income for everyone.

www.youtube.com/tra1776

In the first place, it's not a "radical thought". Many people propose tediously this each and every time there's an New York Times article about Lance Armstrong or cycling.

In the second place, it very obviously does not become "an equal playing field", as anyone who has read about Armstrong's career will know and understand.

In the third place, the sport is called "cycling", not "drug taking". What you propose would be a different sport entirely.

In the fourth place, the drugs are dangerous, and if they were legal, every rider would be forced to take them to be competitive. Your proposal deliberately and maliciously inflicts harm on all riders.

I could go on.

@LHC, I think it can be much more simple than that.

A cyclist's excellent or poor response to doping is independent from his talent for the sport. Which mean that a truly mediocre rider may be fortunate enough to respond very well to doping (Lance Armstrong) and a truly great athlete may have far less benefit from doping. This is why fans and athletes generally object to it. It makes competition meaningless.

Borysewicz left the US Olympic Cycling Coaching under a cloud. It's widely suspected the US Cycling team was blood doping, IE loading up extra red blood cells with pre race transfusions. The technique was well known but no one cared when a noncompetitive  Scandinavian runner showed up to win once every four years.

Arnstrong was a professional triathlete and an amaterur cyclist in 1989, when he caught Borysewicz's eye. The coach encouraged him to focus on cycling, we are told, because it was an Olympic sport.

Clearly, Borysewicz recruited Armstrong to be an amateur -- professionals were not then allowed to compete in the Olympics. Armstrong did compete in the 1992 Olympics, without distinction. He then turned professional, and the rest is history.

Based on his early cycling performance, I think it is fair to say that Armstrong was plenty talented, but that there was no reason to believe he would be the most decorated cyclist in history. It is also clear that the rewards of professionalism attracted him more than the desire to win an Olympic medal.

Neal, we are told, knew that doping was prevalent among the professionals in Europe. Armstrong had to know, too.
Bottom line, Armstrong chose his poison when he had reasonable drug free alternatives -- amateur cycling and competing in triathlons. Myself, I think the best country song lyrics to summarize his broken life are the following:

Your cheatin' heart
Will make you weep
You'll cry and cry
And try to sleep
But sleep won't come
The whole night through
Your cheatin' heart will tell on you...

His sponsors were all aware of the doping issues.  They just conveniently turned a blind eye all those years. Nike, Oakley, Trek...all of them were happy to use Armstrong until the revelation of cheating became a potential public relations nightmare for them. Typical corporate behavior. Armstrong's sponsors are just as dirty and guilty as he is.
Martin,  I think if we let Rachel Maddow scream at them, Putin will run into a cave.  What I don't get is why she doesn't have that effect on you.
Thoughtful. Thanks. Cheating at life is not ok though, there is the line.

Lance, or anyone, could surely train at 7000 feet (like boxers used to do). [You don't have to be rich. If you're good enough in your sport you can surely get the means to train at a higher elevation if you desire.]

You must realize the difference between a physiological response of the body to elevation change and the injection of exogenous erythropoietin (EPO).

I totally agree. Every lay person in American is on some drug or another. We need a testosterone roll-on just to drive our trucks to work and yet, in this hyper-pharmaceutical culture, guys who ride the TdF are not involved. I feel like everyone who followed the Festina affair knew that little had really changed. We all enjoyed Armstrong riding just like we enjoyed Virenque going off for 6 hours through the mountains or Tchmil powering through the mud and on and on. Everyone loved the drama, and even though we all kinda wondered about them braking around the corners of Alpe d'Huez, they were just great rides. Anyone who thought for a minute could know what was going on.

The Armstrong story isn't really much about Armstrong. We're drug addicted but we also love punishment. Armstrong really fulfills our fantasy that cheaters get punished just like after 9/11 he was trotted out to show us that the American spirit can overcome anything. Thankfully, life is more complex.

As a cyclist who only reached the Cat 3 masters I’m far more put off by those knocking Armstrong.
Go to the pool at U Arizona, Flagstaff in the months before the summer Olympics and see how many RICH armatures are there doing training at 7000 feet to up there red blood cell count, same as EPO except Amgen isn’t selling it.
Then there is the really important game, life, how many rhinoplastys, breast implants, and hymen repair/reinstallation, performed by MD(s) are done at your particular major metropolitan hospital?
The values of the press are absurd, cheating at life is OK, doping in major league baseball is tolerated but bicycle racing, in a sport that really requires commitment & stamina getting help is a sin worse than all others.
Hypocrisy, all it takes to write an article like this.
Would you be thrilled by the elite skills exhibited at a World Series Poker match, if they all played with marked cards?

I've been a TDF fan for more than 25 years. Every summer I wait eagerly for the opening day, followed by three weeks of sometimes dull but often exciting cycling. While I regret deeply the use of drugs in the sport, nothing can change the beauty of Lance "dancing" on his bike up the highest mountains in Europe. Cycling remains one of the most challenging sports in the world!
Agree.And I am sure there is similar use of steroids in Hollywood to  give those  middle-aged actors their ripped muscles that they then profit off of.
Doping was the least of it. He is mostly justifiably villified for the people he set out to destroy for telling the truth years before he was ready to admit it.

"Is taking substances, to help him work harder, not less, all that wrong."

Yes, it is wrong. It's amazing that this is even a question. Sportsmanship, which to the detriment of society, has largely become a quaint, forgotten concept.

"Seems like everyone was doing it…"

When you hear this excuse, you can be sure "doing it" is unethical.
if you are not sure let me clarify the matter for you it was wrong and you know it in excusing it you are just as corrupt as he was

I like Lance Armstrong, and I'm not sure that he did anything wrong.  Is taking substances, to help him work harder, not less, all that wrong. Seems like everyone was doing it, and the difference in winning was still the hardwork, determination, perseverance, talent and skill. Having a well calculated diet and supplements regement only a part of that.  I am a fan of Lance Armstong's accomplishments, and they are no less achievements for the doping.  I don't think people are being fair in accusing him of cheating. It was the rules of engagement of the sport, and Lance did well. We should all be proud of him.
NATO doing this in Serbia re: Kosovo was (and continues to be) characterized by the West and its media as an act of liberation. You reap what you sow.

The U.S. has little if any strategic interest in this Russian incursion.  We should be working strictly within the confines of any UN action.  This is not our fight, and Obama's empty threats aren't helpful.
Dr. Einhorn, the testicular cancer specialist at Indiana begs to differ about the faking the cancer. Lance did have testicular cancer.

I have to admit I'm curious about what Armstrong was like outside the cycling world and all the doping. Does his odiousness carry over into his civilian life? What did Crow see in him? Is he a good father?

Not that any of this mitigates his professional behavior. I'm just wondering.

Yes, Carlyle 145, I agree that college debt is a big problem. Worse, it is the Federal Government which is causing most of the problem by charging 11% for college loans (Parents Plus), and guiding families away from paying them off!

College debt is now larger than credit card debt in the US. At the same time, the Federal government lends huge amounts to immoral, amoral banks whose business is largely fraud (read The Big Short for an understandable introduction). And it charges the banks interest that ranges from zero to minus 1%.

This is un-American and intolerable. Senator Elizabeth Warren has proposed equalizing these two interest rates. At least the student loans should be reduced to the level of a home mortgage, around half of what the current education interest rate is. Education is at least as important as housing.

Then families would have a better chance at paying them off. For other great ideas, go to YouTube and watch Comedy Party Platform (1 min 25 sec).

No matter what happens to Armstrong financially from this point on, he will still live far higher on the hog than practically everybody commenting on this article.  He will still have multiple houses, significant income. He just won't have mansions around the world and a private jet.  Or his apartment on Central Park.
Amen Madison- you hit the nail on the head.  It's not been about sport for a long time.  It's all about business. And money. I stopped watching all pro-sports years ago.  It's just a business.

Faked his cancer? that sounds outlandish. It would be a pretty vast conspiracy of liars.

Otherwise sociopathic lying and deception? absolutely true. He has no insight into how awful he is.

You would have thought his early brush with cancer and mortality would have taught him that lesson, but I don't think Armstrong had the mental horsepower to think deeply. He never had to, since from the time he was a child he was held up as a sports prodigy / celebrity. His sense of self and his real place in the world never had a chance to develop.

One also has to wonder how all the drugs he was taking affected his mentality: brain wiring is known to be affected by testosterone - ever hear of roid rage ? With that, and everything else in his system, and given his innate repressed anger over his parents childhood divorce, coupled with his sports celebrity at an early age, it's a wonder he was able to think a normal thought at all. I wouldn't be surprised at all to see one of his attorney's claim some form of mental incapacity as a result of his doping as a defense in his on-going legal battles with sponsors.

Putin was put in a position where he didn't have other choice rather than to occupy Crimea with it's forces. He wasn't looking for that , it is the WEST who destabilized the Ukraine by supporting ARMED opposition to take over the government. Most active groups of this opposition not just hate russians, they are FASCISTS and they don't even hide it. They hate all except Ukrainians, and they are armed with no one to stop them.

Now if Putin doesn't occupy the crimea, predominately russian region, first he would lose support of most russian citizens, not only Crimeans. Crimea was a base of russian fleet for Centuries. No responsible leader would allow to lose that vital base for russian security.

Second, he must stop any attempts from ultra nationalists rusophobic ARMED people from the west of the country to confront russians on the east.

Many here think that Obama seems weak at stoping Putin. But that maybe just a facade and the US had a different aim. And the aim was destabilizing EU-Russian relationship and creating a potential armed conflict in the center of Europe.

The crew of a leader of the Ukrainian Navy "Hetman Sagaydachny" refused to execute orders of the new authorities in Kiev and declared transition to the party of Russia. After joint with NATO of military exercises in Gulf of Aden by the ship the Andreevsky colors were hoisted. Isn't present wishing to be at war for the new power!
Uh, does it matter to you that Lance Armstrong viciously attacked the individuals (e.g., Emma O'Reilly, David Walsh, Greg LeMond, Betsy Andreu) who dared to tell the truth about his doping practices?

Indeed, my friend. No matter what he put into his system, it wasn't the doping that made him great...it was his work ethic when it came to putting in the training.
Taking testosterone, or HGH, or EPO, or Steroids, or the blockers to keep from developing female secondary sexual characteristics due to elevated estrogen levels in men using steroids (a side effect to give any of us men a pause....) none of these things simply produce a champion.

What they do is that champion the same 10-15% edge that all the over riders, who are also using, are ejoying, and that without it, you'd be, de facto, 15% behind.
The drugs were a fact of life. To not take them was like not eating, in that sport. Does that excuse it?
Well, no.
But also, yes...in that it helps us to understand the world in which we live and the rigors of world-level athletic contests.

But it is still true, that no matter what you are "on", the guy who wins the race is the one who when he is training, proves that what he is "on" most, is his bike.
(....unfortunately, this echoes the nike ad, but even they can be like the blind dog, who is also able to find a bone once in awhile)
Like any 10-year child's excuse: "Everyone else was doing it."

Lance got me on the bike, over thousands of miles, MANY MANY climbs. When I was at the worst part of a 130 mile event in the Sierras I'd tell myself "it's just pain, if you quit now you'll never now what the finish is like."
Lance won 7 times against amazing opponents including the East/West matchup versus Ulrich. Then there was the Blue Train of the Posties, poetry in motion never looked so good destroying rivals on a mountain stage as they popped off the back like cheap rivets or as the rocketed through France in the TTT.
Let's be clear- Lance is flawed. Let's be clear Americans- he's the product of a really messed up childhood. He had really bad or absent role models as a child. He had no father, bad stand ins and understandably, an axe to grind.
I wonder which of our MANY heroes are as flawed or worse? JFK, MLK, Clinton, Jordan, Rose, Bonds, McGuire, ARod, etc, etc. And let's be clear, the Tub o' Lard, LeMond freely admits to having "vitamin shots" and "energy boosters" during his training and racing but insists that he was clean!
These guys all have their vices, delights and demons and most get caught. Some are excused (MLK), idolized (JFK, Jordan) but most are hung out to dry once they drop their shield and they can no longer carry the long sword.
Lance rocked. He ruled. He trained in the cols during the winter while Ullrich was at discos drinking and Xing. Lance worked probably harder than others and by the way, demanded his teammates did too.
Allez!

I'll go you one better: why not let them dope and also make it a "last man standing" contest ? Like The Hunger Games, except on bicycles ? Sport has degraded itself to that level, so why not ?

It remains to be seen what the drugs and doping have done to Armstrong's body. Anyone who has doped at at the level and for the duration he has, will certainly be affected as he ages. He has, over and above the earlier cancers, likely greatly shortened his lifespan.

All in the name of winning. Yea, right.
